titleStmt.title: A great fight near Pendennis Castle in Cornwall between the Lord Hopton, and the Parliaments forces, upon the landing of his men for the fetching in of provision; with the number killed and wounded on both sides. Also, another bloudy fight at sea, between a squadron of the Princes fleet, and 18. marchants ships which were coming for London; with the particulars thereof, the number that were slain, two of the enemies ships sunk, and the rest chased to the Isle of Scilley. Together with severall propositions made by the General Councell of the Army; and their resolutions touching the Navy at sea, and the Army in Ireland.

This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

Also, another bloudy fight at sea, between a squadron of the Princes fleet, and 18. marchants ships which were coming for London; with the particulars thereof, the number that were slain, two of the enemies ships sunk, and the rest chased to the Isle of Scilley. Together with severall propositions made by the General Councell of the Army; and their resolutions touching the Navy at sea, and the Army in Ireland.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A GREAT FIGHT Near Pendennis Ca≈øtle in CORNWALL BETWEEN The Lord Hopton, and the Parliaments Forces, upon the landing of his men for the fetching in of provi≈øion; with the number killed and wounded on both ≈øides. ALSO, Another bloudy Fight at Sea, between a Squadron of the Princes Fleet, and 18. Marchants ≈øhips which were coming for London; with the particulars thereof, the number that were ≈ølain, two of the Enemies ≈øhips ≈øunk, and the re≈øt cha≈øed to the I≈øle of Scilley. TOGETHER With ≈øeverall Propo≈øitions made by the General Councell of the Army; and their Re≈øolutions touching the Navy at Sea, and the Army in Ireland.
Imprinted at London for R. W. 2. Aprill, 1649.

div.head: A Bloudy FIGHT IN CORNWALL Between the Princes Forces commanded by the Lord Hopton, and the Parliaments Forces, neer Pendennis Ca≈øtle, and a great Victory obtained at Sea.
div.p:
THe Lord Hopton with 20 Sayle of ≈øhips, lies floting up and downe the Britti≈øh Coa≈øt; in≈øomuch that no ≈øhips can pa≈ø≈øe nor e≈øcape his fury; For, on Tue≈øday la≈øt a Fleet of Marchants ≈øayling towards the Lands-End, were ≈øet upon by the Hoptonians, who coming within ≈øhot of them gave them a broad ≈øide;
but were an≈øwered with the like volley from them again; in≈øomuch, that they came to a hot di≈øpute, the fight continuing many hours, and after the exchange of ≈øeverall tokens from the Sons of Mars, the L. Hopton held off, refu≈øing to fight any longer, and ≈øteered towards the I≈øle of Scilley; the famous ≈øhip called the Culpepper, & about 6 more cha≈øed them about 2 leagues, ≈øunk three of them, the re≈øt e≈øcaped: in this fight many were ≈ølain and wounded on both ≈øides, and one of the Marchants ≈øhips ≈øunk al≈øo, above 100 Mariners ≈øacrificing their lives in this engagement. The fight being ended, the Marchants Fleet hoy≈øted ≈øayl, & ≈øteerd toward the Lands-End; which being done, the Lord Hopton put to Sea again, and (being thir≈øty of revenge) after few hours ≈øayl, he e≈øpyed a prey, who with fury and rage made towards them, gave them a broad ≈øide, ≈øurrounded them (although 8 in number) in≈øomuch that three of them were clo≈øe be≈øet, and ≈øeverall times ready to board; but by their undanted courage and gallantry repul≈øed them, di≈øputed the On≈øet, and were in a good way to have got ≈øafe from them, but a ≈øupply of more ≈øhipping coming afterwards from Scilley, joyned with the fir≈øt Squadron, who by their great potency and ≈øtrength overpowred them boarded the ≈øhips, ≈øeized on all the goods and marchandize, tying every man back to back, ≈øhutting them under Decks, and carryed them pri≈øoners to the I≈øle of Scilley, where they now remain under the barbarous re≈øtraint of Sir George Carteret, the Governour; God in his due time re≈øtore them to liberty, and grant them patiense, in this their time of affliction.

If ≈øpeedy and timely ≈øupplies of ≈øhipping be not ha≈øtned forth, it is to be feared, they will become ≈øole ma≈øters
of the Britti≈øh Seas. Since their taking of the late prize, they have met with another Bristoll ≈øhip, richly laden with cloth, which the Lord Hopton hath di≈øtributed among≈øt the ≈øea-men and ≈øouldiers. He is now ≈øayled towards Milford Haven, but by the way, hee ≈øtruck in at a Creek neer Pendennis, where he landed many of his men for the fetching in of provi≈øion, and other accommodation; but before they could faciliate and accompli≈øh their De≈øign, the Parliaments Forces at Pendennis having notice thereof, a con≈øiderable party of Hor≈øe and Foot were forthwith commanded out, who ha≈øtned to welcome their coming in, and endeavoured to get between them and the water, for the intercepting of their pa≈ø≈øage; but through the malignity of the Corni≈øh-men their de≈øign was almo≈øt fru≈øtrated; for after few hours march they were di≈øcovered, and the Enemy in a po≈øture to receive them, who upon their neer approach ≈øaluted each other with the tokens of Mars, and after a hot conflict the Hoptonians retreated within command of their Ships, our men pur≈øued, kiled 19. wounded many, and made good their retreat with the lo≈ø≈øe of 7 men. Their Ordnance did much retard our pur≈øuit, by which meanes mo≈øt of them got ≈øafe aboard having many Boats in readine≈ø≈øe to receive them; otherwi≈øe few of them had e≈øcaped: ≈øome of the Land ≈øouldiers de≈øerted them at their coming a≈øhore, who ≈øay, That the Lord Hopton is commander in chief of that Squadron, and of all the Land forces thereunto belonging, and that his Colours (or En≈øigns) are yelow, with black bulers in the mid≈øt, and on the top thereof, this Motto written in Characters of Gold, For Charles the ≈øecond.

body.p:
We hear that the Prince of Wales is come to Helver ≈øluce, accompanied by the prince of Orenge, and many other Gentlemen of eminency, and after ≈øome conference between them, his Highne≈ø≈øe took his leave, and took ≈øhipping for Jer≈øey, (as it is reported) who going aboard the Convertine, lanched forth into the Ocean with a plea≈øant Gatle, the great Guns bidding Vale to his departure; there are gone with him the Marque≈ø≈øe of Newcastle, the Lord Culpepper, the Lord Wilmot, Major Gen. Ma≈ø≈øey, and many others; and from Jer≈øey its ≈øaid they are re≈øolved for Ireland, where the Prince intends to ≈øet up his Standard again≈øt the parliament of England, evill Councell prevaile much: the ≈øhips who tran≈øported them from hence were all Men of war, being 8 in number, His Highne≈ø≈øe is very potent, and numerous in ≈øhipping, who ≈øeize and take ≈øeverall prizes at Sea, which doth much propagate their de≈øign; in≈øomuch, that many Engli≈øh Factors, have ≈øolicited Him, de≈øiring that ≈øpeedy care may be taken for prevention thereof, and after ≈øome con≈øultation with his Councell in reference to the ≈øame, He declared, and prom≈øied, That if the Marchants of the City of London would gather and advance the ≈øum of 40000. l. for the maintenance of his Navy at Sea, the like ≈øhould be prevented for the future; and to the end there might be free trading & commerce at Sea, He was re≈øolved to ≈øend a me≈ø≈øage, to acquaint them with the≈øe his de≈øires, &c. The Clergy are exceedingly inraged at the tran≈øactions in England, and do incite the people to de≈øperate engagements for revenge of the Royall bloud, and inve≈øting Charles the ≈øecond in his Throne: But the States at a general councel re≈øolved, That proclamation ≈øhould be made thorow
out the United Provinces, That ≈øuch Mini≈øters as ≈øhould hereafter preach either publikely or privately, any thing concerning State affairs, either in relation to the differences of England, Scotland, France, or el≈øewhere, or ≈øhould hold any private corre≈øpondency from England, or el≈øe-where, as to that purpo≈øe ≈øhould be forthwith bani≈øhed. This Proclamation was proclaimed by Order from the States.

div.p: On the 26 of this in≈øtant we received intelligence that 21 Engli≈øh ≈øhips are lately ≈øeized on at Sea, by Pr. Rupert and his A≈ø≈øociats; ≈øome of whom were of great value: the cu≈øtome thereof, and the two the French took in the ≈øtraits amounting to above 20000. l. Divers other ≈øhips have been al≈øo ≈øeized on neer Rie, Ha≈øtings, and other places.

On the 28. a great ≈øtorm aro≈øe in the hearts of many throughout the Cities of London and West min≈øter, occa≈øioned by the apprehending of Lteut. col. Joh. Lilburn, Mr. Overton, and others, vpon ≈øu≈øpicion of being authors or di≈øper≈øers of a book. entituled The ≈øecond part of Englands new Chains, lately printed and di≈øper≈øed by tho≈øe called Levellers: the Hou≈øe after many houres debate thereupon, voted the ≈øaid Book trea≈øonable, pernicious and of dangerous con≈øequence.

Upon the apprehending of the afore≈øaid per≈øons many jealou≈øies aro≈øe in relation to a ri≈øing within the city for the re≈øcuing of them from the power of the Souldiers; but their Guardiants conducted them ≈øafe to White Hall, and upon Thur≈øday la≈øt the ≈øaid Lieu. Col. Lilburn was brought before the Councel of State ≈øitting at Derby hou≈øe, and upon his examination, declared, That he was a true and cordiall lover of England's peace and freedom, that he would ≈øacrifice his life for the
pre≈øervation of the rights and liberties thereof, and that he would rather ≈øuffer a thou≈øand tortures, then betray his trust, or de≈øert his first principles and engagement. Some other of the Citizens were al≈øo examined, who gave very ≈øtrange An≈øwers, &c.

The Parliament have debated the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of Ireland, and voted Lieu. Gen. Crumwell, Captain Generall of all the Forces which are to be expedited over for the reducement of that kingdom, and bringing of it to the obedience of Parl. He hath declared to the Hou≈øe his willingne≈ø≈øe and acceptance for this pre≈øent expedion; and in order thereunto, ≈øeveral propo≈øitions were propo≈øed and debated, a copy whereof followeth. 1 That ≈øuch Reg. as go may have all their arrears audited, ≈øtated, & Debenters given. 2 That vi≈øible ≈øecurity be given for ≈øo much as ≈øhal appear due, and to be paid to any Tru≈øtee or friend with whom the Debenter ≈øhall be left. 3 That ≈øuch of the army as undertake ≈øhal have their Arrears from the year 1645. fir≈øt paid. 4 That ou ‚Ä¢ of the ≈øix ≈øcore thou≈øand l. per men≈øem, appointed for England and Ireland three moneths pay be carryed over with tho≈øe that go. 5 The privat Soldier & non commi≈ø≈øion Officer to have two moneths pay of Arrears, and all Officers under Captains one moneths pay. 6 That Bri≈øtol, Chester. Leverpool, Beumorris castle, the I≈øle of Angle≈øea, and Milford in South wales, be as Magazines for the Iri≈øh ≈øervice. 7 That a ≈øufficient number of ≈øhips bee employ'd on the Iri≈øh Coa≈øt. 8. That a Court of Admiralty may be erected at Dublin to prevent their frequent comming into England to di≈øpo≈øe of prizes. 9 The pay of the Officers and Souldiers to be according to the Iei≈øh e≈øtabli≈øhment. 10. Provi≈øion to be made for maimed ≈øouldiers, and the widdowes and orphans of tho≈øe ≈ølain. 11. The Parl. forces in Ireland and tho≈øe now going over to be under one e≈øtabli≈øhmen. 12 That 5000 Quarters of Bread and 200. tun of ≈øalt and 200 tun of chee≈ø be tran≈øported with tho≈øe that ≈øhall go over, &c.
